docs.lead_paragraph: Even though the unraveling of the human genome is only now being completed, much of the genetic code has already been claimed for commerce. In what has often been compared to a land grab, companies and universities have filed for patents on hundreds of thousands of genes and gene fragments. Amid concerns that such patents are being granted too liberally and that they could hinder innovation, the Patent and Trademark Office is about to implement new guidelines that will make it harder to patent genes. But critics say the new rules are still too lax.

headline.main: Is Everything for Sale?; Patenting a Human Gene As if It Were an Invention

docs.abstract: Much of genetic code has already been claimed for commerce; companies and universities have filed for patents on hundreds of thousands of genes and gene fragments; Patent and Trademark Office, amid concerns that such patents are being granted too liberally and that they could hinder innovation, is about to implement new guidelines that will make it harder to patent genes; critics say new rules are still too lax; some opponents say it is moral affront to patent living things or parts of living things; they argue that gene is not invention, but something that exists in nature and should be common heritage of mankind; patent office has issued patents on 6,000 genes, about 1,000 of them human genes; some major patent recipients noted; graph; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Even though the unraveling of the human genome is only now being completed, much of the genetic code has already been claimed for commerce. In what has often been compared to a land grab, companies and universities have filed for patents on hundreds...

docs.lead_paragraph: The human genome is in hand. The set of instructions embodied in the ancient chemical deoxyribonucleic acid, at least 3.5 billion years in the making, has been made fully visible for the first time. The manual with the specifications for the human species comes in 24 tapes of DNA, one for every chromosome, each carrying one long, punctuation-free sentence in evolution's four-letter programming code. On first inspection, these ancient texts are as incomprehensible as a message from another planet.

headline.main: Now, the Hard Part: Putting the Genome to Work

docs.abstract: First practical impacts of sequencing of human genome will be in health, with genome widely expected to revolutionize practice of medicine; genome is also expected in time to redefine knowledge of ourselves, our history, our innate capabilities and our relationship to rest of creation; biologists face years of preparatory work in understanding various levels of genome's operation; possession of genome will transform biology, where one gene and protein are studied at time, to scale of operation in which all of cell's genes, or all its proteins, are examined in parallel; slew of new disciplines are emerging to generate and analyze genomic data; diagrams on sequencing genome and on types of analysis that remain to be done; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The human genome is in hand. The set of instructions embodied in the ancient chemical deoxyribonucleic acid, at least 3.5 billion years in the making, has been made fully visible for the first time.    The manual with the specifications for the human...

docs.lead_paragraph: On Feb. 26, 1987, a group of scientists made a thrilling announcement: they had succeeded in locating a gene for manic depression in a large Amish family in Lancaster, Pa. The researchers' finding, published in the journal Nature, made headlines around the world, hailed as the ''first proof'' of a specific genetic mutation underlying psychiatric illness. Mental health experts predicted that the discovery would revolutionize the diagnosis and treatment of severe mental disorders. And many patients and their families felt a new sense of hope.

headline.main: READING THE BOOK OF LIFE: Puzzles of Many Parts; Most Ills Are a Matter Of More Than One Gene

docs.abstract: Scientists seeking genetic causes for manic depression, schizophrenia and other mental disorders now believe such complex illnesses are mediated by multiple genes acting in combination with one another and environment; researchers still argue over how tightly to define such disorders for purposes of genetic studies; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The 223rd session of the New York State Legislature roared to a close Friday, with a head-spinning succession of deals on major issues that made this the most productive session in recent memory. The Senate, the Assembly and Gov. George E. Pataki agreed on a far-reaching package of gun controls, a major overhaul of the state's sexual assault laws and a law providing heavier penalties for hate crimes. On the final day of the session, they reached agreement on a law allowing patients to look up doctors' malpractice histories, a few days after striking a deal on a law requiring parental notification when pesticides are used in schools, and possible neighborhood notification when they are used on lawns.

headline.main: Summary of Major Actions of the Legislature's 223rd Session

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats tonight abruptly forced the first vote of the year on their prescription drug plan, a politically potent issue on the campaign trail, but the measure was swiftly defeated by Republicans. The bill, which would lower drug prices for all Medicare beneficiaries, was rejected by a vote of 53 to 44. Two Republicans voted in favor of the measure; one Democrat voted against it.

headline.main: Senate Democrats Rebuffed on a Drugs Bill

docs.abstract: At a time when public opinion polls show rising prices for prescription drugs as a priority among voters, Senate Democrats seize on parliamentary maneuver to force vote on bill that would lower drug prices for all Medicare beneficiaries, but bill is defeated, 53 to 44; Senate also votes to approve contentious legislation that would delay by one year federal regulations requiring employers to take steps to prevent repetitive motion injuries (M)
